Summary I operate under four main tenants :: 
 
* Foundational skills are essential. They are the key element to research.  
* Integration with Product, Design and Engineering is a key strategy to successful research.  
* Relationships are fundamental in my line of work and lead to trust.  
* Building bridges across and within teams leads to company success and better outcomes.

Experience Sr. Manager, Research PubMatic April 2015  – Present (5 months) Sr. User Experience Design Researcher Yahoo! February 2013  – Present (2 years 7 months) Sunnyvale, CA * Employ a variety of methods such as lab-based usability, unmoderated usability, surveys, observations and interviews  
* Built reputation of a robust comprehensive analytical approach utilizing Grounded Theory and triangulating qualitative data with web analytics, market research and secondary data (e.g. comScore) 
* Communications, verbal and written, to all levels within Yahoo's largest organization from Sr. VP and VPs to peer level product, engineering and design groups 
* Proud to research some of Yahoo's most complex platforms in advertising (e.g. programmatic buying) and analytics (e.g. service engineering network health monitoring) while staying current with consumer based inquiry (e.g. mobile, log-in workflow) 
* Directed several initiatives developing user researcher team's skills including engineering talks (Q2 2013) and an internal conference aimed at sharing best practices (Q3 2014; Yahoo Research Summit) 
* Member of hiring committee involved in identifying (e.g. conferences, networking), screening and interviewing candidates  
* Received formal documented recognition such as "Lightening Speed" (x2), "Winning Team" and "Do Good" Lead User Experience Researcher Yahoo September 2014  –  March 2015  (7 months) Sunnyvale Lead research across several products and domains ranging from B2B and consumer mobile and desktop applications. Actively involved in scoping, prioritizing and managing the many aspects of research, while also responsible for the tactical execution of research on one of Yahoo's most successful advertising platforms. Areas of focus include Yahoo Gemini (advertising), Yahoo Publishers, Personalization and Security and Accounts. Experience User Experience Researcher Brillio (contractor for Microsoft, Xbox team) July 2011  – Present (4 years 2 months) Redmond, WA Lab studies 
- Developed and executed all research lab studies on voice and gesture input for Xbox One. Authored all reporting documentation, presented all research findings to key stakeholders. 
- Developed and executed all research for Xbox 360 scorecard testing, a rigorous series of lab evaluations of the 2011 update to Xbox Live system. Protocols supported cross-moderator consistency across 3 researchers and many laboratory assistants. 
- Created quantitative analytical tools and processes that were subsequently adopted by the team. 
 
Technical Writing 
- Wrote and/or edited a series of documents summarizing high-level research insights about HCI. Documents integrated original Xbox research with literature review. This work underscored a new process of working with key stakeholders that was proactive, rather than reactive/evaluative. 
 
Field Research 
- Lead researcher and moderator on Golden Path, a longitudinal field research program documenting the end-to-end Xbox consumer experience from initial product demand through use over time.  
- Determined appropriate research and moderation protocols for field interviews. Protocols supported cross-moderator consistency. 
- Partnered with team members in reporting results through qualitative & quantitative analysis, and relating end-user stories through high production value video. 
 
Product Impact 
- Input research drove major design changes into the UI that strongly improved the user experience.  
- Scorecard research drove usability improvements into 2011 release, impacted 2012 design planning. User Experience Researcher Blink Interactive (contractor) November 2009  –  December 2011  (2 years 2 months) Seattle, WA Conduct usability research for various clients in Information Technology fields; analyze data, recommend changes, and present findings to clients. 
Plan & execute lab studies on pre-release hardware; conduct field research and competitive analysis for product planning. User Experience Researcher Microsoft (Windows Home Server team) November 2005  –  November 2009  (4 years 1 month) Core Role 
- Solely responsible for all user research for Windows Home Server V1. Designed research plans and conducted ethnographic studies (site studies, interviews, longitudinal studies) and focus groups. Drove experimental design and conducted usability studies (cognitive walkthroughs, lab studies) for all high-priority product features. Designed research schedule to meet product needs. 
 
Product Impact 
- Shipped Windows Home Server V1. Developed, published, and evangelized three user personas for Windows Home Server. United the team in understanding our users; initiated team’s transition from dev-focused to user-centered design. Created team interest in meeting users; over 75% of team attended site visits and lab sessions. Developed reputation as trusted advisor to PM and Dev; regularly consulted on UI decisions throughout the product cycle. 
- Used lab studies and walkthroughs to evaluate UI; filed usability bugs and pushed for fixes. 81% of bugs filed for V1 were resolved as fixed; follow-up studies verified improvements in user experience. 
- Used longitudinal field research study to identify issues with Windows Home Server in a real-world family context not visible in testing environments. Strong product reviews from participants were later used in public marketing campaigns. 
 
Team collaboration 
- Frequently partnered with PM, Dev, Design and UA in preparing and executing research studies. Created HTML prototypes for Windows Home Server usability testing on as-needed basis. 
- Worked with Product Planning on market research surveys for Windows Home Server target market; conducted drill-down quantitative data analysis to map user personas to target markets. 
- In addition to Windows Home Server, acted as usability consultant to Small Business Server team. User Experience Researcher Aditi (contractor for Microsoft, Windows Server Solutions Group) October 2004  –  October 2005  (1 year 1 month) Redmond, WA Core Role 
- Owned all usability research for Small Business Server 2005 release, and consulted on Windows Home Server and other Windows Server products. Drove experimental design and conducted usability studies (card sort, lab, walkthrough) for high-priority features on all supported products. 
- Designed and executed research plan to update and expand two user personas for Small Business Server. Conducted field research to update and expand seven Windows Server IT Pro personas. 
 
Product Impact 
- Drove early information architecture models for Small Business Server and Windows Home Server with data from card sorts. Revealed user experience challenges early in product cycle using lab tests and paper prototypes, and provided design fixes. Published and promoted user personas internally; all personas were adopted across Windows Server Division. Summary I make things easier to use--and I love it. 
 
I feel privileged to be able to speak with users to learn their frustrations and pleasure points about a product and then turn that feedback into recommendations for my clients.  
 
I still can't believe I get paid to do it. 
 
I've used focus groups, usability tests, in-depth interviews, comparative tests, design walk through tests, RITE methodology, direct mail optimization, competitive tests, card sorting, modified field studies, and expert reviews to gather user insights. 
 
Sharing these insights with clients has allowed me to help shape recommendations which improve their websites and products, ultimately making a more pleasurable experience for the end user. 
 
I've used Axure to produce prototypes based on recommendations from testing to show developers and product management my design ideas. The ability to incorporate changes based on user feedback is a profound shift from merely suggesting changes to the development team and I am really enjoying it! 
 
Specialties: I can make users of all types feel at ease which helps them to communicate any issues and/or good things about a product. I have great working relationships with a vast array of clients. I'm well versed in the Agile methodology and will happily talk your ear off if you ask how UX should be integrated in to it. I am a quick learner when it comes to technology and am an advanced user of Morae, Photoshop, Tobii and SMI Eye Trackers and Software, GoToMeeting, WebEx, and Office. Metro Area I am a manager in the Data Collection Methodology and Research Branch (DCMR), in the Economic Statistical Methods Division (ESMD). I am responsible for leading the design and testing of large-scale government data collections. Currently, I am working on surveys for the U.S. Bureau of Economic Analysis (BEA) and the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD). Survey Statistician (Survey Methodologist) U.S. Department of Energy January 2011  –  September 2014  (3 years 9 months) Washington D.C. Metro Area I was a survey research methodologist at the U.S. Energy Information Administration’s (EIA). I provide consulting services on the measurement of energy constructs, survey design, sampling, and data analysis. My primary responsibility was to meet with program offices in the Office of Energy Statistics, identify their research objectives for new and existing data collections, and operationalize these research objectives into concrete constructs that can be measured. I also acted as an advocate for respondents that must complete EIA’s forms. To do this, I regularly met with respondents to cognitively test survey questions and conduct usability testing on the mode the survey questions were being administered. Using the findings from these meetings, I wrote reports and made recommendations to EIA’s senior executives on ways to reduce the respondent burden while increasing the validity of the data collected. This resulted in decreased costs associated with data collection (i.e., reducing nonresponse) and data processing, saving taxpayer money. Management Analyst U.S. Coast Guard April 2013  –  September 2013  (6 months) Washington D.C. Metro Area I was selected to participate in a six month detail at the U.S. Coast Guard, Department of Homeland Security, as a part of the President’s Management Council (PMC) Interagency Rotation Program for high performing GS-13s through GS-15s. This opportunity was comprised of two activities: First, I attend monthly PMC meetings with other participants and learn about best practices in management, such as managing multi-generational work forces, managing using your strengths, and workshops on applying to the Senior Executive Service. Second, I was a Management Analyst on the Mission Management Staff at the U.S. Coast Guard. My primary responsibility in this position was to conduct in-depth interviews with program offices to document existing processes using Visio, analyze these processes, and recommend changes to make these processes more efficient; resulting in reduced bureaucracy, which saves the U.S. Coast Guard and taxpayer money. My secondary responsibility in this position was to conduct quality management reviews of Coast Guard field offices’ prevention departments. The purpose of these quality management reviews is to ensure compliance with U.S. Coast Guard requirements and International Maritime agreements. Survey Statistician (Survey Methodologist) & User Experience (UX) Researcher US Census Bureau November 2009  –  January 2011  (1 year 3 months) Washington D.C. Metro Area I was a member of the Response Improvement Research Staff and provided survey research methodology consultation to program offices in the U.S. Census Bureau’s Economic Directorate. My main responsibilities were to manage the lifecycle of research projects and conduct qualitative and quantitative research with companies throughout the United States to assess the effectiveness and efficiency of the surveys and their associated materials. This included developing project management schedules for complex research projects, leading client meetings, writing findings and recommendations reports, and presenting research results and recommendations to both technical and non-technical audiences, including senior executives. I was also responsible for conducting empirical research to help better understand behavioral aspects of survey response and presenting the results at international conferences. The ultimate goals of these activities were to reduce burden on companies, improve the quality of the data collected, and to reduce costs for the U.S. Census Bureau’s Economic Directorate. I managed all phases of the survey lifecycle, which included managing project costs and timelines, designing surveys, analyzing large data sets, and presenting the findings to senior executives at Fortune 500 companies and state tourism offices. Summary I am a design researcher, user experience designer, community-builder, librarian, and photographer. I currently work full-time as a Senior User Experience Researcher at Mozilla where I lead research for Firefox Mobile. I have a passion for learning about people and designing meaningful products and experiences for global audiences. My goal is to use my work to make people happier and the world better. 
 
On the side, I organize the Chicago UX Book Club and chiDUXX, a networking and mentoring group for Chicago women in technology. I occasionally take on freelance UX and photography work to continue to learn and to expand my creativity. Feel free to contact me if you are interested in collaborating. Summary As an experienced UX researcher, I get to ask “Why?” every day, and from large amounts of data, I see the connections between disparate data points which will drive design strategy and help improve the products & services which people have come to rely on in their digital worlds (and sometimes in their physical ones).  
 
I imagine the future through understanding the present, and use insights to deliver innovative evidence-based digital strategy across projects & channels, aligned with larger company vision, objectives and KPIs. 
 
I believe that the interactions we have with every product & service are essentially a conversation - making content not "just about copy”, with a focus on understanding the Information Experience in order to provide the relevant and necessary elements of our side of the conversation to address user needs. In short, a bad UX is a poorly understood conversation, which we can continually learn from, refine and design better. 
 
In addition to traditional tactical research work, I am experienced in: 
• Designing & leading both small, moderated research engagements as well as large-scale, high-touch, global research programs 
• Designing & delivering conceptual/strategic research for thought leadership 
• Interacting with & interviewing a wide variety of user types (including experience with special populations such as cognitively-impaired individuals) 
• Bespoke approach to research methodologies including remote usability feedback sessions,  
well-planned guerrilla research, diary studies, observational studies, mental models, personas,  
user journeys and design research 
• Liaising between professionals in the field and special user groups 
• Building & maintaining high levels of user engagement over long research engagements 
• Large-scale mixed qualitative & quantitative analysis 
• Disseminating results clearly & successfully across project teams 
• Designing/facilitating design ideation workshops & tangible prototyping Summary As an experienced UX researcher, I get to ask “Why?” every day, and from large amounts of data, I see the connections between disparate data points which will drive design strategy and help improve the products & services which people have come to rely on in their digital worlds (and sometimes in their physical ones).

Summary I am an experienced user research with a passion for learning how people use technology. Empathy, understanding, the voice for the people using the product- these are the elements of user research that drive me to keep doing what I do. Some of my passion areas for research include social interactions, games user research, developer tools/research, and new/emerging technologies. 
 
In my free time I work with friends to organize The Great CouchCon, a Greater Seattle area-based micro-convention dedicated to playing local multiplayer/couch coop games and getting player feedback for game designers who demo their game at the con. Summary Human Factors and Usability Expert fostering relationships between humans and technology. 
 
Facilitating the development and design of easy to use, memorable, and immersive experiences by maintaining the voice of the user throughout the entire design process. 
 
Life goal: To break down self-imposed societal biases and limitations, to make the uncomfortable more comfortable, ultimately encouraging society to demand more approachable and sustainable design from all products and services they encounter. Experience User Experience Researcher and Designer Nike September 2014  – Present (1 year) Portland, Oregon Area Within the Nike+ team, my role has taken on the form of an internal consultant for design research, human factors, usability, and user advocacy. I soak up the internal plans, and the external demands, all in the name of helping our Product and Design teams generate the most empowering experiences for our users. 
 
You might find me... 
- collaborating with Business Development and Product teams to create research strategies and test plans throughout the product roadmap 
- designing and administering field and remote research sessions with small and large user groups, including but not limited to: surveys, in-depth interviews, contextual inquiries, workshops, intercepts, wear and fit testing, lab-based fitness tests 
- producing timely and concise reports, analyzing and synthesizing quantitative and qualitative research results, that are shared with various internal teams 
- tirelessly keeping the voice of the user at the forefront of design efforts 
- illustrating use cases and workflows to surface areas where we create the best solution for our clients 
- supervising and collaborating with outside consultants and agencies when appropriate 
- promoting a healthy apetite for research-driven decisions through the quick wins achieved from usability tests and prototyping User Experience Designer General Motors July 2013  –  September 2014  (1 year 3 months) Warren, Michigan Research, design, and testing of infotainment systems and in-vehicle components across GM brands - mostly focused on Cadillac. Striving to create the safest, most easy-to-drive, and enjoyable in-vehicle experience. 
 
- defined HMI functional specification for the North American and Global Markets 
- coordinating design implementation across multiple international OEM suppliers 
- lead in-vehicle experience for Telephony, OnStar, 3rd party infotainment, and device connectivity across full line of GM vehicles 
- participated in feature planning and scope definition, achieved through user studies, research, and leadership and stakeholder interviews 
- defined OnStar operation procedures for all human-to-command-center interactions 
- coordinated and lead a variety of in-vehicle usability clinics including: static and dynamic in-vehicle field studies, driving simulation tests, and basic screen prototype tests User Experience Designer Vectorform June 2013  –  August 2013  (3 months) Royal Oak, MI Contract position defining and designing the workflow of automotive companion apps. Additionally, I provided usability feedback on various approved projects, and research and validation for future projects. User Experience Designer and Researcher Chartbeat November 2012  –  June 2013  (8 months) Manhattan, NY Lead research to discover new ways to gain meaningful, actionable insights from the data collected in the digital advertising space. Worked closely with advertisers and publishers to achieve the most transparent understanding possible of their daily lives. Collaborated with Engineers and Designers to produce fully functional prototypes, which were rigorously tested and improved upon. Summary I am a strong leader with the ability to communicate effectively across a broad array of markets, fields, professions and people. I am a decisive, transparent, and independent thinker who will act for the common good of the product and team.  
 
I'm currently working on user-centered, design-driven solutions that engage with multiple disciplines including anthropology, psychology, government, industry, telecommunications and more. These currently include: 
 
— User research and analysis for Fortune 100 companies' web applications and workflow navigation. 
— Developing effective and Agile training systems in User Experience and Design Research for recent design graduates. 
— Workflow failure analysis and rapid redeployment to meet content needs. 
— Intricate and effective persona development that reflects a truly empathetic effort.

— Design Education, Interaction, User and Experience Design 
— Persona development and journey mapping 
— User testing methods and platforms 
— University Education 
— User-centered design 
— Wireframing 
— Contextual interviewing and moderator guides 
— Technical analysis systems including Morae and Tobii systems 
— Adobe Creative Suite 
— Rapid, iterative prototyping

Summary Anthony is a User Researcher currently working with Concur Technologies, previously with Microsoft, AT&T Mobile, and POP! Multimedia (web design agency). He has worked on numerous communications, hardware, and software products, and is capable of providing insightful research-based solutions to usability problems in any of these spaces. He has over 9 years of research experience using the following methodologies: Iterative, Formative, and Scorecard lab studies, Cognitive Walkthrough, Field studies, Heuristic evaluation, Structured interviews, Focus groups, Hardware "Form" studies, and Qualitative data analysis. Additionally, Anthony gained extensive experience with website design and development through the 3 years he worked at POP! Multimedia where he worked on many projects ranging from small local bank and e-commerce sites to internationally renowned performing arts organizations. 
 
Research Methodology Experience: 
• Lab usability studies (formative, Iterative, benchmark, and scorecard) 
• Field studies 
• Qualitative data analysis 
• Hardware “form” evaluation studies 
• Structured interviews 
• Cognitive walkthroughs 
• Heuristic evaluations 
• Focus groups

Experience Principal Omni-Channel User Experience Researcher Nordstrom March 2012  – Present (3 years 6 months) Greater Seattle Area Currently leading new UX research strategies to measure success of in-store concept pilots (in limited stores) prior to full launch. Qualitative data from customers and salespeople, usage and conversion data are included to inform a holistic picture. My other focus is "discovery"​ research, necessary to understand process (e.g. shoe fitting, mobile device usage, etc) to inform online and in-store features (e.g. way-finding) and identify typical journeys.  
 
I conducted the first UX studies in the Customer Experience Center (a mock store) to evaluate two end to end cross-channel journeys created with a small working team that were based on existing data from across the company and primary research (using storyboards, surveys, interviews, focus groups, usability studies etc). This led to the physical manifestation of each journey through the lens of our Personas, including touch points like contextual in-store notifications, a Digital Directory and an Interactive Digital Mirror. 
 
I have introduced process improvements that have increased customer empathy, awareness of our team and improved our impact. Including: live study observation, report templates, standardized severity ratings and rating scales, study announcements, observation guidelines, peer reviews, and screener revisions to align with Personas and other data teams. 
 
Part of a team responsible for the creation/socialization of Nordstrom Personas based on customer segmentation data and requiring cross-team collaboration (e.g Consumer Insights, Photo and Video studios, et al).  
 
Conducted workshops to introduce early design activities/tools such as the Personas, and Design and Reality Mapping; mentored and co-led sessions so others could learn and conduct on their own. 
 
Gained approval and funding to build 2 multi-purpose user research labs and introduced "active"​ observation methods. Currently driving efforts to use the CEC as a "lab", testing technology prior to placing in store. User Experience Researcher JPMorgan Chase September 2011  –  March 2012  (7 months) Seattle, WA Senior User Experience Researcher, Retail Customer Experience Amazon.com December 2008  –  July 2011  (2 years 8 months) Seattle, WA Member of 2-4-person team responsible for conducting UX research for the Retail Customer Experience organization. Conducted over 50 studies with 20 teams, including traditional and remote usability studies, field studies, quantitative surveys, and remote testing for Amazon.com and subsidiary sites such as Endless, Amazon Fresh. Conducted specific field studies to understand help inform the beginning of Amazon Clothing by a deep study looking at shopping behaviors in the home and online. 
 
Collaborated as full member of the design team for Amazon Wine, originally a standalone site, requiring significant custom work including persona creation, design mapping, competitor research in the early design phase and multiple rounds of usability testing with varying levels of prototype fidelity. 
 
Established and maintained multiple participant databases to recruit and schedule for studies.  
Introduced new methodologies for information architecture testing, including large- scale online card sorting and tree-testing of Amazon’s global and select storefront navigation and quantitative baseline usability testing of product pages using Keynote. 
 
Responsible for managing and upgrading existing labs and led effort to determine requirements and design of new research labs for the SLU campus, moving from a simple Morae setup to using multiple PTZ cameras for recording and observation of studies. Senior User Experience Researcher, Digital Media Amazon.com May 2006  –  December 2008  (2 years 8 months) Seattle, WA Amazon’s Digital Media team was responsible for all digital media projects including: Amazon Unbox (now Amazon Instant Video) client and website features, Amazon MP3, Your Media Library (a digital library with social networking), the Amazon Online Reader/Search Inside the Book, the Digital Text Platform (for Kindle self-publishing), the Kindle and Digital 1-click purchasing.  
 
As the sole user researcher on the Digital team, I supported all digital products, using early design research techniques (e.g. literature reviews, competitor evaluation (when available), persona creation, and cross-functional design mapping sessions) to inform product requirements for client-side and website features. Conducted over 30 research studies on these features when in delivery (traditional usability studies, beta testing, and quantitative surveys, and testing of software and hardware for Kindle). Also participated in design reviews and helped determine metrics needed for clickstream analysis post launch product, including ref-tag structure consultation. User Experience Researcher Amazon.com September 2004  –  May 2006  (1 year 9 months) Seattle, WA The Shopping Experience team was responsible for providing research support for all tools and features that help customers shop on Amazon.com, establishing industry commerce standards for Community and Personalized Recommendations features, the homepage, product pages, and global navigation.  
 
Emphasis of primary research conducted included: the introduction of Prime and 1-click purchasing, A9 Search, Search Inside the Book, and community-based projects such as Customer Reviews, Amazon “Plogs”/Amazon Connect (a feature that allowed direct connection with authors and their readers) that helped to drive other community related features such as Amazon Profiles and Customer Discussions and early stage research for Amazon’s digital products. 
 
Conducted 50 studies with over 30 teams, including traditional usability studies,and quantitative surveys; in addition used early design research techniques (card sorting, focus groups, persona creation and design mapping) to help inform product requirements. Established and maintained participant database to recruit and schedule for studies, and documented the process for other researchers. Led efforts to outsource in-house recruiting efforts leading to hiring of a usability lab coordinator. Games Researcher Microsoft Games Group January 2002  –  March 2004  (2 years 3 months) Redmond, WA Experienced with working across many game genres, having contributed to released titles such as Brute Force, Project Gotham Racing 2, Tao Feng, Voodoo Vince, Amped, Halo for PC, various casual games on MSN Zone and the multiplayer interface for Xbox Live. 
As a contractor, designed and performed usability studies and playtests on first generation Xbox games and PC titles in development with the goal of evaluating and improving the entire gameplay experience. User Research Assistant Stanford University 2000  –  2001  (1 year) Stanford, CA, Redwood Shores, CA Stanford’s Advanced Eye Interpretation Project team joined with Oracle to conduct an eye tracking study to inform search behaviors and usability of a web portal application prototype; this study used early eye-tracking equipment and software. 
 
Worked with Oracle's Advanced User Interface team and aided with study design and participant recruitment. Responsible for conducting all study sessions, including the calibration and placement of a head-mounted eye tracking device on each participant. Helped to then manage, code, and analyze initial data. 
 
Eventual findings resulted in design recommendations for the portal and general industry recommendations on eye tracking for usability evaluation still in use. User Research Assistant Softbook Press 1999  –  2000  (1 year) Menlo Park, CA Softbook Press, a Silicon Valley based startup, introduced one of the first eBook readers in 1998.  
 
Conducted literature reviews on typefaces/formats (ClearType, OEB) and benchmark testing of both hardware and UI (including download time testing) for the first versions of Softbook eBook reader and it's only competitor, Rocketbook. Also conducted primary research for the 2nd generation that focused on hardware (e.g. viewing angle polarization, page turning), UI for the Reader, eBooks and an eBook publishing tool. 
 User Research Assistant for the Stanford-Poynter Project Stanford University 1998  –  1999  (1 year) Stanford, CA The Poynter Institute partnered with Stanford University to conduct the first eye tracking study of online news (as well as one of the earliest studies to apply eye tracking of internet content). In this study, 67 frequent Internet news consumers participated in order to observe how they read news online using eye tracking equipment (head-mounted) and analysis software built by the Stanford team.  
 
My primary role in this study was to manage and manually code the screens viewed 
by format (headlines, articles, briefs, photos, etc.) and topics (science, medicine, 
10 national, international, etc.). 
 
The Stanford eye tracking development team then overlaid eye fixations to gather page entry points, fixation and reading order of content which was then analyzed by primary researchers (Marion Lewenstein, Deborah Tatar and Andrew DeVigal). User Research Assistant for Web Security Study Stanford University July 1998  –  September 1998  (3 months) Stanford, CA This Web Security study was designed, analyzed and published by Ed Felten (Princeton) and Batya Friedman (University of Washington); funded by the NSF.  
 
Seventy-two individuals, 24 each from a rural community in Maine, a suburban professional community in New Jersey, and a high-technology community in California participated in an extensive semi-structured interview that characterized users’ conceptions of Web security. 
 
My role was to help execute the 2-hour interviews with software professionals in the Silicon Valley which included standardized interview questions concerns about risks and harms of Web use to themselves and to society, hand drawn visualizations of a secure connection and feedback on 'cookies' and browser ui used to indicate secure connections. 
 Computer Camp Instructor American Computer Experience July 1997  –  September 1997  (3 months) Stanford, CA Camp Instructor for ACE (American Computer Experience), a for-profit organization which ran summer camps for children ages 7-16 at university campuses across the United States. 
 
Specifically, conducted classes with 7-11 years olds focused on BASIC programming and held classes for 12-16 year olds on C programming. Summary Henry is an experienced Senior User Experience (UX) Researcher. He conducts custom User Experience (UX) Research (Qualitative and Quantitative), Usability Testing, and the occasional Market Research study, for Fortune 100 companies. 
 
He recently presented a Mobile UX Research workshop at UXPA Boston in Spring 2015.  
 
He is highly experienced in testing Mobile sites and apps, which has been his latest focus. He is also highly experienced in testing traditional devices and UIs such as desktop, TV, laptop, etc. He also is experienced in Medical Device testing for the FDA's 510 (k) submission process.  
 
His favorite UX Design tools are Sketch and InVision. 
 
The specific types of studies he conducts include:  
Eye Tracking (ET Glasses and Monitor-SMI Eye Trackers and Software), One on One Interviews / In-Depth Interviews (IDI), Focus Groups / Triads, True Intent / Voice of the Customer (VOC), Intercept Surveys, Feedback Surveys, Remote Online Unmoderated, Remote Online Moderated, Usability Testing, FDA 510(k) Submission Research, Market Research Surveys, Shop Along study, Diary Study, Ethnography, Competitive Benchmarking, Card Sort, Navigation Studies, Mock-up / Prototype Testing, Expert / Heuristic Review, Hispanic Market Research, LGBT Market Research, Market Segmentation, and other types of quantitative and qualitative research.  
 
UserZoom, Morae, SMI Eye Tracker / Glasses, and OptimalSort / OptimalWorkshop are some of his favorite UX Research tools.  
 
He has a love for science, nature, problem solving, and technology. In his spare time he enjoys exploring the outdoors and drawing. 
 
He loves to travel to NYC, and plans to live there one day. He also visits San Francisco several times a year, especially during the chilly New England Winters.
